item.title: Artists We Lost in 2025, in Their Words
item.description: Robert Redford, Roberta Flack, Diane Keaton and Brian Wilson are among the cultural luminaries who died this year.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Cohn
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Neal Boenzi/The New York Times; Fairchild Archive/Penske Media, via Getty Images; Jack Robinson/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images; Sara Hirakawa for The New York Times; Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Robert Redford, Diane Keaton, Roberta Flack, David Lynch, and Brian Wilson.

item.title: Miracle on 64th Street: Options for Holiday Opera
item.description: Usually, holiday opera is scarce on major stages in New York. But this year, there are two at Lincoln Center alone.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Albert Rhodes Jr. and Joyce DiDonato, center, in Gian Carlo Menotti’s opera “Amahl and the Night Visitors” at Lincoln Center Theater.

item.title: ‘Jingle All the Way,’ and the Super Bad Dad Superhero
item.description: Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sinbad, Phil Hartman and Rita Wilson served a platter of high-octane holiday high jinks in this unhinged 1996 comedy.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: In These K-Dramas, Women Are Unjustly Accused (Maybe)
item.description: Netflix’s “The Price of Confession” and Hulu’s “Nine Puzzles” are thrillers with complicated plots and complicated protagonists.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:credit: Netflix
item.media:description: Jeon Do-yeon, left, and Kim Go-eun play women who share an unlikely rapport in “The Price of Confession.”

item.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs’s Lawyers File Appeal, Arguing His Sentence Was Unjust
item.description: The mogul’s lawyers say that a judge issued an excessively steep sentence for prostitution offenses after Mr. Combs was acquitted of more serious charges.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Mark Von Holden/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sean Combs was convicted of arranging for the travel of male escorts across state lines but acquitted of sex trafficking and racketeering conspiracy.

item.title: The Rockettes, at 100, Need a Kick in the Right Direction
item.description: This year, “Christmas Spectacular Starring the Radio City Rockettes” pays homage to the legacy of the group, but its future seems to be more about sisterhood than dancing.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rockettes performing “Parade of the Wooden Soldiers” in 2010.

item.title: A Game Studio’s Banner Year: Avowed and The Outer Worlds 2
item.description: Although video games are taking longer to make, a studio renowned for immersive experiences managed to release three this year.
item.dc:creator: Lewis Gordon

item.title: Review: ‘The Seasons’ Jumbles Warnings About Climate Crisis
item.description: An operatic Vivaldi pastiche, with a new story by Sarah Ruhl, offers an ambivalent message about how art can make people pay attention.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert

item.title: Sydney Sweeney’s Offscreen Image Contrasts With Progressive Onscreen Roles
item.description: Onscreen, she tends to play women fighting the patriarchy; offscreen the image she cultivates has meant conservatives consider her one of their own.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: On ‘S.N.L.’: Bowen Yang’s Farewell and Ariana Grande
item.description: Hosted by Ariana Grande and featuring Cher as its musical guest, the show had plenty of holiday tunes and a satirical greeting from President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: NBC Universal, via YouTube
item.media:description: Ariana Grande, left, and Bowen Yang on “S.N.L.” Yang played a dedicated eggnog server during his final shift at a Delta lounge in Kennedy Airport.

item.title: Review: A ‘Picnic at Hanging Rock’ Musical Is a Psychedelic Parable
item.description: At Greenwich House Theater, Greta Gertler Gold and Hilary Bell’s stage adaptation of Joan Lindsay’s novel hovers between reverie and reality.
item.dc:creator: Brittani Samuel
item.category: Picnic at Hanging Rock: The Musical (Play)
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Kate Louissant, Gillian Han, Tatianna Córdoba and Carly Gendell at the Greenwich House Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: White House Chides Smithsonian for Delayed Turnover of Programming Records
item.description: The institution has tried to work with the administration’s demands that it present a more uplifting view of American history.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Smithsonian Castle, home of the Smithsonian Institution administrative offices and information center, in August.

item.title: Aimee Ng Knows the Secrets of the Women on the Frick’s Walls
item.description: Aimee Ng, the museum’s new chief curator, broke out of the academic mold with a video series called “Cocktails With a Curator.” Here’s how she’s drawing new audiences.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Starr
item.media:credit: Sara Messinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aimee Ng, the Frick Collection’s chief curator, with “Comtesse d’Haussonville” by Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, 1845, in Henry Clay Frick’s bedroom.

item.title: Robert Nakamura, ‘Godfather’ of Asian American Film, Dies at 88
item.description: In his work, he often returned to Manzanar, the camp in which he and his family, along with thousands of other people of Japanese descent, were interned during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: 10 Songs That Explain My Year
item.description: From Gustav Mahler to Lady Gaga, a peek into Lindsay’s past 12 months in music.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Nicholas Albrecht for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tracy Chapman

item.title: British Police Drop Case Against Bob Vylan After Its Anti-Israel Chant
item.description: Bob Vylan, a punk-rap duo, caused international outrage by chanting the message at the Glastonbury music festival this year.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Glastonbury Festival of Contemporary Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jewish groups, as well as Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, had condemned the chant as hate speech.

item.title: Russell Brand Is Charged With Additional Counts of Rape and Sexual Assault
item.description: The actor, comedian and YouTuber now faces seven counts of rape and sexual assault in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Reuters
item.media:description: Russell Brand at a London courthouse in May.

item.title: ‘Sinners,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and the Art of Racial Solidarity
item.description: Across film (“Sinners,” “One Battle After Another”), theater (“Ragtime”) and TV (“The Lowdown”), four works suggested what achieving racial equality in America would take.
item.dc:creator: Salamishah Tillet

item.title: ‘The Queen of Versailles’ Bombed on Broadway. What Went Wrong?
item.description: The show reunited Kristin Chenoweth and Stephen Schwartz for the first time since “Wicked.” It wasn’t enough to counter poor word of mouth and other challenges.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Queen of Versailles,” which opened at the St. James Theater on Nov. 9, was adapted from Lauren Greenfield’s 2012 documentary about a couple seeking to build a palatial home in Florida.

item.title: What Song Did You Discover, or Rediscover, in 2025?
item.description: We want to know why it resonated with you.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: In Ontario, the Uplifting Case of a Ballet Company’s Stolen ‘Nutcracker’ Sets
item.description: Ballet Jörgen’s holiday scare reaffirmed its mission: taking the art form to remote towns and outposts where most people have never seen a pas de deux.
item.dc:creator: Martha Schabas and Brett Gundlock
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times

item.title: 7 Takeaways From the Final Episodes of Taylor Swift’s ‘The End of an Era’
item.description: Seven takeaways from the final episodes of “The End of an Era,” the Disney+ series exploring her globe-trotting concert extravaganza.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times

item.title: Influencers Get Their Night at the Opera as the Met Courts New Fans
item.description: The Metropolitan Opera has invited 70 influencers to help convince a younger, online audience that opera isn’t scary or even unaffordable.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Anthony Steverson, Tiffani Singleton, Taryn Smith and Tracey Thomas were given the run of the Metropolitan Opera to make social media content.

item.title: 9 Artists to Watch
item.description: A gifted Queens rapper (Lexa Gates), a noisy British band (Maruja), a Drake-approved emo songwriter (Julia Wolf), a lo-fi power-pop project (Sharp Pins) and more.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: The Best Animated Shows and Movies of 2025
item.description: Yes, “KPop Demon Hunters” makes the list. But that was just one of the standouts in a great year.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry’ Scores Big With Hockey and Sex
item.description: Adapted from romance novels, this Canadian series has been a surprise hit for HBO Max.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Heated Rivalry” has been a life-changing break for the stars Hudson Williams, left, and Connor Storrie.

item.title: From ‘Buckeye’ to ‘Mona’s Eyes’: 5 Breakout Novels of 2025
item.description: These days, most best sellers are written by authors with household names. Not these five breakout books.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Kate Winslet’s Unhappy Family Christmas
item.description: The British actress’s directorial debut, “Goodbye June,” is based on a script written by her son and follows a fractured family reuniting in the hospital over the holidays.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford and Thea Traff
item.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times

item.title: May Britt, 91, Dies; Her Marriage to Sammy Davis Jr. Sparked Outrage
item.description: She was a white actress, he was a popular Black entertainer, and their relationship elicited racist reactions in 1960, worrying John F. Kennedy’s presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Hulton Archive/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ms. Britt and Mr. Davis at their wedding in November 1960. It was reported that the event had been delayed from October at the request of John F. Kennedy’s presidential campaign to avoid negative attention before the election.

item.title: Lawmaker Sues to Remove Trump’s Name From the Kennedy Center
item.description: Representative Joyce Beatty, Democrat of Ohio, argues that only Congress is authorized to rename the D.C. performing arts institution.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s name was added to the facade of the Kennedy Center last week after its board voted to rename it.

item.title: Two New Banksy Murals Appear in London
item.description: Two new London murals, widely attributed to the mysterious street artist, combine seasonal themes with what appears to be social commentary on rising child homelessness in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A new mural by the artist Banksy appeared in Bayswater, in central London, on Monday.

item.title: Vince Zampella, Formative Designer of Call of Duty Games, Dies at 55
item.description: Mr. Zampella co-founded two game studios and also worked on the Medal of Honor, Titanfall and Battlefield franchises.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vince Zampella in 2014. He helped found Infinity Ward and Respawn Entertainment.

item.title: Chris Rea, Grammy-Nominated Singer of ‘Driving Home for Christmas,’ Dies at 74
item.description: A blues-influenced singer and guitarist, he built a lasting career, particularly in Europe, with hits like “Driving Home for Christmas” and “Fool (If You Think It’s Over).”
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Brill/ullstein bild via Getty Images
item.media:description: Chris Rea performing in Cologne, Germany, in 1998. A virtuosic slide guitarist, he found fame and success, particularly in Europe, with a sound that blended blues, soul and soft rock.

item.title: Playwrights Horizons Is Sued Over Discounts to People of Color
item.description: The lawsuit, against the prominent Off Broadway theater, is backed by Edward Blum, who has long challenged race-based policies. Playwrights called it “meritless.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson

item.title: Jerry Kasenetz, a King of Bubblegum Pop Music, Dies at 82
item.description: With his producing partner, Jeffry Katz, he made lightweight ditties like “Yummy Yummy Yummy” that soared up the charts in the late 1960s.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jerry Kasenetz, center, in 1968 with his producing partner, Jeffry Katz, right, and Neil Bogart, an executive at Buddah Records. As the founders of Super K Productions, Mr. Kasenetz and Mr. Katz turned out a slew of hit records.

item.title: Barry Manilow Is Diagnosed With Lung Cancer
item.description: The “Mandy” and “Copacabana” singer said he would undergo surgery to remove a cancerous spot on his left lung, and he postponed several concert dates.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a statement on Monday, Barry Manilow added that his doctors did not think the cancer had spread.

item.title: Reading ‘A Christmas Carol’ Aloud, and Leaning Into Its Dark Side
item.description: An actor at the Dickens Museum in London is delivering dramatic performances of the classic holiday tale, just like the writer himself once did for sold-out crowds.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Rayfield and Alice Zoo
item.media:credit: Alice Zoo for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Cover-Up,’ Plus 8 Things on TV This Week
item.description: A documentary about the journalist Seymour Hersh premieres, and lots of shows wrap up their seasons.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Seymour Hersh in 1975.

item.title: James Ransone, Actor Known for ‘The Wire,’ Dies at 46
item.description: The character actor had grown up in Maryland, where “The Wire” was set, and went on to star in horror films like “It Chapter Two.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:credit: Jeff Vespa/WireImage, via Getty
item.media:description: James Ransone in 2015.

item.title: Kevin Arkadie, ‘New York Undercover’ Co-Creator, Dies at 68
item.description: The screenwriter and producer created several television hits about law enforcement. He made one of the first police dramas to star two main characters of color.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Earl Gibson Iii/Getty Images
item.media:description: Kevin Arkadie, a co-creator of “New York Undercover,” died Wednesday at 68. He was best known for working on several popular police dramas.

item.title: ‘Orwellian Climate of Fear’: How China Cracks Down on Critics in the U.S.
item.description: The Chinese government once focused on political dissidents and exiled activists. Now, federal officials say, it is targeting artists in the United States whose creative protests test its tolerance.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker and Alicia Chen
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Move Aside, Snowflake: ‘Theater Kid’ Is the New Go-To Political Insult
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, New York’s mayor-elect, is among the latest politicians to be tagged with the term, raising the question: What did theater kids do to deserve such scorn?
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Gaye Gerard/Getty Images
item.media:description: A stage production of “High School Musical” in Sydney in 2008. Theater kids became an indelible part of the culture when “High School Musical,” “Glee” and “Smash” hit the airwaves.

item.title: Robert Mnuchin, Stock Trader Turned Art Dealer, Dies at 92
item.description: A major player in the block-trading boom, he left Wall Street for the art world, winning a Jeff Koons sculpture at auction for $91 million in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips
item.media:credit: David Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Mnuchin at Mnuchin Gallery in 2019. “I’ve loved art for so long, I was looking for a way to become even more involved,” he told The New York Times in 1992 after opening his first gallery, C&M Arts.

item.title: Bowen Yang Is Leaving ‘S.N.L.’
item.description: Yang, who joined the NBC sketch show in 2018, earned five Emmy nominations during his run.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.media:credit: Will Heath/NBC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Bowen Yang’s memorable “Saturday Night Live” characters include the iceberg that sank the Titanic.

item.title: As the ‘Avatar’ Villain Varang, Oona Chaplin Blazes Her Own Fiery Path
item.description: She had been working with refugees and channeled her anger over their situation into the ferocious performance, which was filmed several years ago.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh

item.title: Cheyenne Jackson Believes in Kindness as a Drug
item.description: “I don’t do drugs anymore,” the actor and singer said, “but when a random baby in a stroller smiles at me, it feels like I just did a bump of coke.”
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck
item.media:credit: Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images for Glaad

item.title: Lou Cannon Dies at 92; Journalist Chronicled Reagan as an Author
item.description: He was a foremost authority on the president, tracing his career in unvarnished accounts from his time as California governor through his years in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Allan Ludwig, ‘Founding Father’ of Gravestone Studies, Dies at 92
item.description: His Pulitzer-nominated book “Graven Images” inspired a reassessment of Puritan art, challenging the belief that imagery carved on headstones was meaningless.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Kennedy Center, Memorial to JFK, Is Trump’s Now, Too
item.description: The Kennedy Center installed President Trump’s name on the facade of the arts center, which had been designated as a living memorial to President John F. Kennedy.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crew members unveiling the new name of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Friday morning.

item.title: Rachel Reid Put the Heat in ‘Heated Rivalry’
item.description: Thanks to a steamy television adaptation, Rachel Reid’s romance novels about closeted hockey players have become mainstream best-sellers.
item.dc:creator: Angelina Mazza
item.media:credit: Carolina Andrade for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s been surreal,” says Rachel Reid, the author of the Game Changer romance series, outside her Nova Scotia home.

item.title: Rafael Ithier, Ambassador of Puerto Rican Music, Dies at 99
item.description: Leading the acclaimed salsa group El Gran Combo de Puerto Rico, he brought the music of his native island to a worldwide audience for more than 60 years.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.category: El Gran Combo de Puerto Rico
item.media:credit: Lynne Sladky/Associated Press

item.title: What We Know About Rob Reiner’s Final Projects
item.description: The release of a “Spinal Tap” concert film that was filmed at Stonehenge has been delayed.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.category: Spinal Tap at Stonehenge: The Final Finale (Movie)

item.title: Museum of the Earth and Its Fossil Collection Fight Their Own Extinction
item.description: A funding crisis at the Museum of the Earth and the Paleontological Research Institution in Ithaca, N.Y., could scatter priceless specimens and end nearly a century of pioneering research.
item.dc:creator: Becky Ferreira and Kristian Thacker
item.media:credit: Kristian Thacker for The New York Times

item.title: Theodor Pistek, 93, Oscar-Winning ‘Amadeus’ Costume Designer, Dies
item.description: He worked on more than 100 films, but that wasn’t all: He was also a racecar driver and a painter of photorealistic works, many depicting cars.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:credit: Michal Krumphanzl/CTK Photo, via Alamy
item.media:description: Theodor Pistek in 2017. A racecar driver, artist and costume designer, he was best known for creating clothes for two Milos Forman films set in the 18th century, “Amadeus” and “Valmont.”

item.title: Carrie Coon and Tracy Letts Want to Get Under Your Skin
item.description: The couple are gearing up for the Broadway opening of “Bug,” about a descent into paranoia and psychosis in a squalid motel room.
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:credit: Caroline Tompkins for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Cast Says Goodbye to the Netflix Series
item.description: Nearly a decade after the hit sci-fi horror series debuted, cast members including Finn Wolfhard, Gaten Matarazzo and Maya Hawke gathered in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Lanna Apisukh
item.media:description: Members of the “Stranger Things” cast, above, said they planed to watch the series finale together.

item.title: Romeo Santos and Prince Royce Want Bachata to Share in Latin Music’s Boom
item.description: Despite huge collaborations, top-selling albums and sellout tours, the leading stars of the Dominican genre still feel like they haven’t received their due.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times
item.media:description: In November, Santos and Royce — who had never before collaborated — released “Better Late Than Never,” a joint album. Next year, they’ll tour together.

item.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
item.description: In this month’s picks, torrents, trolls and time travel.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Five Free Movies to Stream
item.description: The final column of the year looks at the end of things — the end of the world, the end of youth — along with an underrated holiday gem.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Hear James Baldwin, E.E. Cummings, Mary Oliver, and More
item.description: Rare recordings of E.E. Cummings, Mary Oliver and more offer a tour through literary history led by authors in their own words — and voices. Take a listen.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris and Aliza Aufrichtig

item.title: ‘Oh, Mary!’ Came to London. It’s the Raciest Show in Town.
item.description: Some had wondered how the show about Abraham Lincoln’s wife would fare after its creator left the Broadway cast. But mirth is abundant as it opens on the West End.
item.dc:creator: Matt Wolf
item.media:credit: Manuel Harlan
item.media:description: Mason Alexander Park brings physical brio to the role of Mary Todd Lincoln.

item.title: He Smeared Dog Feces on a Critic. Now, He’s Back in the Spotlight.
item.description: Two years after the assault, Marco Goecke is staging a nontraditional “Nutcracker.” Ballet Basel hopes the focus will stay on his choreography.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Christophe Gateau/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Marco Goecke in the Hanover State Opera in 2019.
